habitat_description:
Great Plains:
In Colorado, this species occupies grassland over the Great Plains as well as agricultural lands (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). They are adapted to a narrow range of conditions, requiring deep sandy to loamy soils that are well drained but moist (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). In Colorado, they typically favor light soils of considerable depth especially in the sandhills and other wind-blown soils (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). Most often found in soft alluvial soils of arroyo bottoms and floodplains (Findley et al. 1975). Found in eastern plains of New Mexico (Findley et al. 1975). Fossorial species, dens underground in extensive tunnel systems (NatureServe). Pocket gophers are ecologically important as prey items and in influencing soils, microtopography, habitat heterogeneity, diversity of plant species, and primary productivity (NatureServe). The Plains pocket gopher is a solitary animal; lives within loose "colonies" (NatureServe). Population density averages 4-5 individuals per acre (NatureServe). Found at elevations ranging from 914 to 1980 meters (Shrupp and Cade 1989). Prefers open lands such as prairies, pastures, cultivated areas with deep, friable, moist soils; e.g., sandy or moist alluvial soils in Oklahoma. Also oak-hickory savanna, oak savanna mixed with maple-basswood forest, mesquite prairie, prairie-deciduous forest mosaic (Williams, in Wilson and Ruff 1999; Heaney and Timm 1983)(quoted directly from NatureServe). Intensive agriculture and human development (highways and presumably other impervious surfaces) may limit potential range extension (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998). In Texas, this species inhabits sandy soils > 10cm in depth (as deep as 67.5cm) and avoids clay soils. They feed on roots and stems of mainly weeds and grasses. (Schmidly 2004).
